intro: Lemna blatteri, commonly known as the floating leaf lettuce, is a small, aquatic plant belonging to the duckweed family. It forms dense mats on the surface of freshwater bodies, with its tiny, broad leaves floating just above the water. The plant lacks true roots and instead has root-like structures called rhizoids that anchor it to submerged surfaces. Its rapid growth rate makes it an effective colonizer of still water environments. Botanically, it is characterized by its simple morphology and ability to reproduce both sexually and asexually.
